title: The Course and Consequences of Inflation
sub_head: The growth rate in the money supply has been slowing substantially.
body:
Aharon Friedman and Stephan Miran’s “The Inflation Tax on Capital” (op-ed, July 19) nicely illustrates the randomness of the effective capital-gains tax rates caused by inflation. Even if the legislated rates are progressive, a high-income taxpayer may still pay a lower effective rate on real capital gains than would a lower-income taxpayer if the latter held an asset during a long inflationary period.
The capital-gains tax can also exacerbate losses. Imagine you had a $100,000 portfolio of assets intended for a down payment in May 2020. You decided to put it in a very conservative portfolio that earned you only 4% over the year. Since inflation in that period was 5.4%, you can no longer afford the same basket of goods. Yet the IRS will still tax the $4,000 you “gained,” deepening your losses. These distortions should stop. Social Security is indexed, and so are tax brackets and the standard deduction. We should tax only real capital gains.
Prof. S. Abraham Ravid
Yeshiva University
New York
